newsitem.title: JAPAN: MOF says to deal seriously with DKB if laws broken.
newsitem.headline: MOF says to deal seriously with DKB if laws broken.

text.p: Japan's Ministry of Finance said on Friday it would deal seriously with Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd if the bank were proven to have violated laws.
A MOF official told reporters that the bank may have falsified reports to the ministry in past regular inspections with the aim of avoiding an accurate assessment of its problem loans.
"This act could be in violation of Japan's banking laws," the official said.
The bank earlier on Friday announced that its president and chairman would resign to take managerial responsibility for its involvement in a scandal surrounding a corporate "sokaiya" racketeer.

Earlier this week, Dai-Ichi Kangyo was raided by prosecutors investigating the bank's links with the "sokaiya", who has been accused of taking illegal payoffs from Japan's top brokerage, Nomura Securities Co Ltd.
"It is quite regrettable that a financial institution with high public standing such as DKB has undermined the trust of depositors," said the official.
He said the ministry has instructed the bank to check if it has made similar questionable loans to others.

Japan's banking law bans financial institutions from making false reports to the ministry when the ministry conducts inspections, the official said. Any banks which violate the law must pay a fine of up to 500,000 yen, but no banks have ever been fined.
"Considering the fact that no banks have ever been punished under the law, it would be a very hard social punishment if any banks were to be punished," he said.
"At any rate, we will take some action against DKB at the stage when facts become clear," he said.
The ministry will check if DKB has had a sufficiently sound management system and if the bank has adequately fulfilled its public role, he added.
